Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Feedbacks Between Human Community Dynamics and Socioecological Vulnerability in a Biodiversity Hotspot

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will focus on people, community organizations, and the long-term health of natural ecosystems that support people's livelihoods. Early research on human well-being and the environment showed that strong, collectively governed institutions help people to manage common lands in ways that enhance ecosystem services and quality of life. This knowledge has been a key facet of biodiversity conservation and resilience of rural societies worldwide. Some communities are able to adaptively manage their natural resources much better than others under conditions of rapid change and uncertainty. What factors enable collectively governed management institutions to effectively respond to potentially catastrophic environmental disturbances? In rural societies that are urbanizing, activities of daily life increasingly take place outside the family home, in "non-family organizations" that expand people's perspectives and choices, such as schools, stores, employers, and health clinics. These non-family organizations are not collectively governed and have no clear constituents or responsibilities other than to respond to supply and demand for their services, goods, and experiences. In this project, the researchers will test the hypothesis that the responsiveness of resource- management institutions to rapid environmental change is ultimately tied to the distribution and types of market-driven, non-family organizations within communities. They will conduct their research in the forested buffer zone of the Chitwan National Park, Nepal, a biodiversity hotspot that is home to the endangered Bengal tiger and more than 200,000 Nepali people who live and farm nearby. One of the world's most invasive plants, Mikania micrantha ("mile-a-minute weed") recently has spread through community forests and degraded critical ecosystem services that affect wildlife habitat and the livelihoods of residents. To explore the links among non-family organizations, management institutions, and the spread of Mikania, the researchers will collect social and ecological data in 21 heterogeneous community forests to develop models of social-ecological vulnerability and resilience to environmental change. They will conduct two experiments to test the relative strength of factors related to Mikania success, including an educational intervention with management institutions, and a common garden experiment that manipulates environmental variables linked to Mikania growth.

This project will test the ability of the "family modes of organization" framework, a powerful explanatory tool in demography, to identify factors that cause coupled natural and human systems to be vulnerable or resilient to rapid change. The project will be an exemplar of "translational science," interdisciplinary research focused on practical solutions to current problems. The investigators will translate research findings into local action through an intervention aimed to slow the catastrophic spread of invasive, exotic species that threatens biodiversity and human well-being. More broadly, the research will aid sustainable development efforts in other settings in south Asia and the Pacific through partnership with a non-profit organization focused on solving issues in agriculture and the environment. The project also will provide education and training opportunities for a new cohort of junior scholars by involving them in interdisciplinary, international research focused on real world problems and their solutions. This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Invasive species threaten local ecosystems and the livelihoods of people embedded in these systems. Our study site in Chitwan, Nepal, exemplifies the difficulties invasive species present to people in rural areas. In this largely agricultural community, households collect fodder, fuelwood, and thatch from local lands including private property, common lands, community forests and protected national parklands. How households use these lands depends not only on the household's livelihood strategy, but also on multiple organizations and institutions. Governance institutions, such as community forest committees, regulate use of community forests. Non-family organizations, such as businesses, markets, and stores, provide households with alternatives to direct resource collection. It is not well understood how invasive species affect a complex intersection of social, ecological, and institutional factors.

We collected data from multiple components of this socio-ecological system to better understand the impact of ecosystem change brought by invasive species (the most serious being Mikania micrantha, a rapidly growing invasive vine). We conducted interviews with approximately 1250 households to measure their consumption and resource collection behaviors. The surveys were a combination of standard interview questionnaires plus an innovative touch tablet interface that allowed respondents to indicate, with high spatial precision, where in the forests they collected resources. We also surveyed 21 community forest management committees along with local organizations and institutions. We enumerated relevant non-family organizations in the households' neighborhoods. Finally, we conducted ecological measurements in 2219 plots in the community forests and assessed the presence of invasive species, plant diversity, canopy cover, and disturbance indicators. Soil analyses were taken on a subset of these plots.

Our research findings emphasize the importance of governance institutions, such as community forest management committees, in organizing collective action that could manage Mikania. We found large variation in these management committees: wealthier committees had greater governance capacity and potential for community action, such as organized Mikania removal efforts in the forests. In addition, trust between management committees, individual households, and governmental agencies affects communication and potential for action. Our findings highlighted the role of perceptions as a factor of household participation in Mikania management activities. When a household perceived Mikania as more harmful, the household was more likely to engage in Mikania removal, suggesting households are following their self-interest. Self-interest and a rational choice approach, however, likely does not completely explain households' behaviors. Our research using agent-based modeling shows that a cultural diffusion model may better describe how households engage in Mikania management behaviors. It is also important to understand how human interactions with the environment may encourage Mikania dispersal and establishment. We found that the presence and abundance of invasive species, like Mikania, are related to human-caused activities, like thatch collection, and environmental disturbances, such as flooding.

Our research also generated methodological findings. To ensure our measurement of human behaviors was spatially referenced, we developed tablet software that featured zoomable satellite imagery and allowed household respondents to indicate where they collected forest resources; management committees indicated where they engaged in different management practices. We compared the accuracy of spatial data collected from tablets to spatial data collected from paper maps from a related project and found that even in the setting of Chitwan, where not all respondents had familiarity with touch screen devices, tablets let to higher accuracy in the data. We extended the eigenvector spatial filtering (ESF) approach to testing the impact of neighborhoods on individual decision-making. We also developed a discrete choice modeling approach to solicit potential behavioral and attitudinal changes under a set of hypothetical conditions.

Our project had broader impacts for junior scholars and the study site. Multiple undergraduate and graduate students worked on the study and received training and professional development. To enhance their research, several students earned competitive fellowships to support their work, including a NASA Earth and Space Science Fellowship and a Fulbright Award. In addition, staff from our research partner organization in Nepal were trained in ecological, statistical, and demographic methods. One of our activities was an experimental demonstration conducted in the community forests comparing four different Mikania management treatments over three years. Members of the community forest participated in the treatment administrations each year. Throughout the project, we conducted stakeholder meetings among local people, scientists, research scholars, representatives of government and non-government agencies, and community forest management committees, which are crucial for building a foundation for interdisciplinary research and translating research findings into forest conservation policy and practice. The final stakeholder meeting focused on the status and issues of invasive plant species and the efficiency of current and modified control techniques towards decreasing the presence of invasive plants. For further outreach, we created informational and instructional posters tailored to each community forest, buttons, a project overview video, and presentations to describe the ecological impacts of our findings.
